"ian.mayo" wrote:
> 
> I'm keen to minimise the amount of data transferred, so don't want to
> pass all task attributs for all queries.
> 

REST is an architectural style favoring the large-grain transfer of
data; as per Fielding, 5.1.5:

"The trade-off, though, is that a uniform interface degrades
efficiency, since information is transferred in a standardized form
rather than one which is specific to an application's needs."

Don't be too keen to optimize your way around REST... the result is an
undefined architectural style, as opposed to a clearly-defined style
guided by constraints.

>
> I've had a look at the Google APIs, and Google has a 'fields'
> parameter in the URL.  I've had a go at implementing this, but it
> makes my lovely tidy RESTUL URLs look ugly and difficult to
> read/review.
> 

REST has nothing to do with your URI pattern.  If your URIs become
difficult to maintain, yeah that's a problem, but not one that has to
do with REST.

What I'm saying is, if your assumption is leading you in a direction
you don't want to go (request parameters), perhaps you should question
your assumption.

Designing responses which are cacheable creates more real-world
bandwidth savings, than designing responses which are more granular and
application-specific.  This is counter-intuitive, but a key aspect of
the REST style.

-Eric
